habitat: Common in woods, heathland, and short grass from autumn to winter. Widely distributed across Europe and Asia.
shortDescription: Resembles an edible puffball but has firmer flesh and a dark interior early in development. Releases spores by breaking up, not through a single opening.

identification.cap: 4–12 cm across, 3–6 cm tall. Tough, dirty-yellow to ochre-brown skin with coarse, warty scales.
identification.gills: No gills - this is a puffball-type mushroom
identification.stem: No stem, attached to soil by mycelial threads.
identification.flesh: Whitish when young, becoming purple-brown to black with white 'veins' as it ages.
identification.microscopicFeatures: Spores are spherical and spiked. Spore mass is grayish, becoming purply-black and powdery. Outer skin ruptures to release spores.

note: First described by Persoon in 1801. Scleroderma means 'hard skin', and citrinum refers to its 'lemon-yellow' color. Close relatives of boletes.
